results.title: Global insights 4
results.creator_credit: Ntennis Davi, Campbell Manderson, Tom McKendrick and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
Global Insights 4 is a compilation of short video works of a subversive political nature, sourced from videoactivists, cultural saboteurs and ‘serious’ documentary-makers from around the world.
Pieces featured include an alternative US response to the incidents of September 11 2001, made by Indymedia NYC soon after the event; scenes from the front line of the democracy struggle in Malaysia. A remarkable sequence of (unarmed) indigenous peasants in Mexico taking over an army base; a Korean perspective on the rise of the new global economic orthodoxy and the resistance to it; the ‘no borders’ movement in Europe and Australia against the deportation and detention of refugees.
Adverts peppered throughout the program are actually ‘subverts’ - biting satirical 30-second statements about consumerism, gender, sexuality and possibilities for reshaping the world. Producers of this form range from disaffected advertisers to teenagers with an ironic message about climate change.
The Global Insights videos have seen hundreds of free public screenings from Tamil Nadu to Antarctica - inspiring grass-roots people’s action and fostering an independent and accessible screen culture globally.
Global Insights is put together on a miniscule budget by volunteers. It is a collaboration between hundreds of independent media makers around the world.

results.title: Nice time
results.brief_description: An observation of couples and youths at night around London’s famous Piccadilly Circus. Influenced by the Free Cinema movement, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner allow the camera to observe the scenes of people milling in front of cinemas, walking around the Circle and attempting to get into night clubs. There is no voice over, and instead, it is the observational mise-en-scene and the almost relaxed detachment of the observing camera that creates a leisurely but intriguing glimpse into everyday pleasure and life. The decision of the Swiss directors, Goretta and Tanner, to travel to the UK to involve themselves in Free Cinema was an indication of the immense influence the movement was having on documentary filmmaking, an influence that was to lead to the radical aesthetics of “cinema verite”.

results.title: Ungry ug
results.brief_description: Cute claymation about curious Caveman ‘Ug’, who is feeling very ‘ungry. Luckily Ug spots a small dinosaur running past. Sounds like and easy meal, or is it?

results.title: Sadness: a monologue by William Yang
results.creator_credit: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on photographer William Yang’s one-man stage show, ‘Sadness’ is a journey into the past and a heart-breaking testament to the significant traces people leave behind. Through the use of slides, oral history and stylised recreations, Yang investigates the murder of his Uncle Fang Yuen in the sugar cane fields of North Queensland. Running alongside this narrative is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. What emerges is a powerful requiem for the dead and the lasting legacy that family and friends have on the living.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia

results.title: Tales from two schools
results.brief_description: Work created by students from Tarnagulla and Marong primary schools with animator Paul Fletcher as part of the Artists in Schools Project sponsored by the Department of Education and Arts Victoria. Contains original artwork by the students (from lower primary levels) that has been animated by the artist, footage of the students and animations created by the older students. Storyline is minimal but includes a flying potato adventure, a monster circus and experimental animation.

results.title: [Watching television]
results.brief_description: Short comic film made in 1958 by Graham Foster and friends to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as ‘a mini sitcom’ the film features a group of friends engrossed in the act of watching television and has a voiceover by Foster. Features television advertising from the late 1950s. Companion piece to ‘A Kiwi in Exile’.

results.title: Interviews with the builders of ACMI @ Federation Square
results.brief_description: There are two segments - the first with Philip Walsh walking down and back along the old platform 15, 16 during demolition and the second part (and the priority) is of Don Bates presenting the drawings to Nigel Milan from SBS
